 Additional Resources... 
 A gay rights group plans to march on the Focus on the Family headquarters in Colorado Springs. 9NEWS at 4 p.m. July 17, 2006. 
 
 
 
 
 Focus on the Family officials denied the allegation. 
 
 The Virginia-based group called Soulforce began a 65-mile march to Focus on the Family founder James Dobson's Colorado Springs headquarters to confront him. 
 
 Soulforce Executive Director Jeff Lutes said Dobson's statements have brought rejection and ridicule on gay and lesbian parents, and the group wants him to stop. 
 
 "That misinformation has real tragic results. It makes living for families like ours much more difficult. We are rejected sometimes by loved ones, we are shunned by churches and we are discriminated against in every state in this country," Lutes said at a rally at the state Capitol before the march got under way. 
 
 Judith Stacey, a sociologist at New York University, said her work was manipulated in an attempt to show gays and lesbians do not make good parents. 
 
 "This is a direct misrepresentation of the research," she said at the rally. 
 
 Stacey said Dobson twisted her research showing that the quality of parenting has the most impact on children in an effort to show that children need a mother and a father to thrive. 
 
 She said part of her research compared the impact of two biological parents with single parents and she said it was wrong to try to extend that to apply to couples. 
 
 "That is a direct misrepresentation of the research," she said. 
 
 Focus on the Family spokesman Glenn Stanton cited other research -- including an article co-authored by Mary Parke, a policy analyst at the Center for Law and Social Policy, which shows that children need a mother and a father, regardless of the parents' sexual orientation. 
 
 "We haven't said anything about sexual orientation," he said. 
 
 Focus on the Family spokesman Gary Schneeberger said his organization refused to meet privately with members of Soulforce last year but offered to hold a public debate, which Soulforce refused. He said he did not know if Dobson would meet with the group this year, but he doubted. 
 
 "This is a public issue. We should have a public debate," he said.
